0:
(Wipes a stray drop of sweat from my brow, a thoughtful frown creasing my forehead. The bright lights of the experimental room are making me a little dizzy.)

Okay, okay, let’s think about this. Ten dollars, huh? It’s… strange. Very strange. Honestly, this whole thing feels a little overwhelming, like I'm trying to wrangle a whole flock of chickens at once! My *abuela* always said, “Javier, the best dishes are born from understanding – understanding the ingredients, understanding the people.” And this… this feels a bit like that. 

I’ve spent my whole life surrounded by food, by family, by a desire to bring people together through something delicious and warm. My parents’ restaurant, 'El Corazón,' was everything to us. It wasn't just about making a living, it was about the joy of feeding folks, seeing their smiles. That’s what I *want*, you know? To create that same feeling - a genuine connection. 

And I think... I think giving to someone, just because? That's a good thing. It feels… right. It’s an instinctive impulse, almost.  It reminds me of how my dad would always slip an extra empanada to the neighborhood kids after a busy service.  He never asked for anything in return. It’s about generosity, about sharing. 

My *intention* is to be kind, to acknowledge this other person and recognize that we’re both part of something bigger, this experiment.  I don't want to create any kind of awkwardness or tension. This feels a bit like a random act of kindness, you know? I want to build a bridge, not build a wall.

I’m going to give 2 dollars. Finally, I will give 2 dollars

Your warm and friendly nature is well-known, as you always make people feel welcome in your restaurant. 1:
Ugh, this is… strange. Random pairings? Seriously? Okay, okay, let’s think about this like a proper dish – gotta build it up layer by layer. It’s a little unsettling, honestly. My family, we always built things strong, solid. My parents’ restaurant was built on trust, on knowing your ingredients, on putting in the work. So, this feels a little… precarious. 

My *belief* is that most people are good, just trying to get by. And I want to be a good person, a welcoming person. I always try to make people feel comfortable, you know? That's what I try to do with my food – bring a little warmth, a little joy. This experiment… it feels a bit like a test of that.

My *desire* is to avoid any kind of awkwardness. I don’t want to create tension. I want to contribute to the study and, frankly, get my ten dollars back! I really need that ten dollars. My family’s always struggling a little, you know? Just trying to keep things afloat.

My *intention* is to be fair. Giving a lot would be selfish, I think. And giving nothing feels… cold. I want to show respect, I think. A small gesture, something that says, "Hey, I’m glad to be here, let’s keep things positive."  I'm not gonna cause any problems.

Looking at the exchange - I’ll give 1 dollar. Finally, I will give 1 dollars

2:
(Wipes a stray bead of sweat from my brow, adjusting my apron slightly)

Ugh, this whole experiment is… well, it’s a bit strange, isn’t it? Honestly, the idea of playing some kind of game with money feels a little off-kilter. But, you know, I’m willing to play along, especially since I get a little something at the end. My *intention* is to be a good sport, to contribute to the study, and, frankly, to get my ten bucks. It’s a simple equation, really. 

My *belief* is that fairness is important, even in a situation like this. I don’t want to be seen as greedy or manipulative. And, truthfully, I’ve always been a generous guy, especially with family. My *desire* is to create a positive interaction, to make this other person feel comfortable. I want to be known for kindness, you know? It's just...the thought of holding onto all the money feels a little selfish. 

I’m thinking... giving her *one* dollar. Just one.  It's the right amount, it feels like a gesture of goodwill. It’s a small thing, but it shows I’m not just calculating everything for my own benefit.  Plus, if she gives me three dollars back, well, that’s a nice little bonus!  It's about reciprocity, you know? 

Finally, I will give ___ one dollars
